content: The islands are a year-round tourist destination
- Portugal's Vasco da Gama explores the Seychelles.
- French planters and their slaves begin settling in the Seychelles.
- Britain annexes the Seychelles, which are then administered from Mauritius.
- Seychelles become a separate British colony.
- First elections to a legislative council take place.
- First political parties are formed: France Albert Rene's socialist Seychelles People's United Party and James Mancham's pro-business Seychelles Democratic Party.
- The Seychelles Democratic Party wins legislative elections.
- Seychelles become independent and are governed by a coalition, with James Mancham as president and France Rene as prime minister.
- Rene's supporters stage a coup against Mancham ostensibly without Rene's knowledge; Rene installed as president.
- Rene enacts a new constitution, turning the Seychelles into a one-party state.
- South African-based mercenaries try but fail to restore Mancham to power.
- Army mutiny thwarted.
- President Rene restores multiparty democracy.
- Rene re-elected in multiparty ballots.
- Rene's Seychelles Progressive People's Front wins 30 out of 34 seats in parliamentary elections.
September - President Rene wins another term in office with 54% of the votes, beating opposition candidate Wavel Ramkalawan who won 45% of the votes.
December - President Rene's Seychelles Progressive People's Front wins parliamentary elections, but the opposition Seychelles National Party increases its presence from one to 11 seats.
July - Economic reforms are introduced under which Seychelles will pull out of the Southern African Development Community (SADC) and close three diplomatic missions.
April - President Rene steps down, replaced by former vice president James Michel.
December - Widespread damage is reported after giant waves, generated by an underwater earthquake off Indonesia, hit three islands.
July - President Michel wins presidential race.
October - Parliament bans political or religious organisations from running radio stations, sparking a rare outbreak of unrest.
May - The ruling SPPF wins early elections. They were brought forward after opposition MPs boycotted parliament over moves to ban political parties from owning radio stations.
November - International Monetary Fund agrees a two-year $26-million rescue package for the indebted Seychelles economy.
January - President Michel asks creditors to cancel half the archipelago's $800 million foreign debt. The economy has been hit by reduced tourist traffic and turmoil in the world's financial markets.
April - Somali pirates move their operations southwards to Seychelles and beyond as patrols are stepped up in the Gulf of Aden.
October - US says it will supply Seychelles with drone spy-planes to help fight piracy. France offers legal help.
November - Seychelles, European Union sign anti-piracy agreement which will allow EU troops to be deployed on the islands.
World Bank approves $9 million loan to help indebted Seychelles to restore economic stability.
July - First successful prosecution of pirates in Seychelles. Eleven Somalis are jailed.
August - Seychelles signs up to International Criminal Court.
May - President Michel re-elected.
April - A US drone crash lands after take-off from the islands, which are reportedly being used as a base for flights monitoring pirates and Somalia.

April - Sakher El Materi, the son-in-law of ousted Tunisian president Zine al-Abidine Ben Ali,  is granted asylum in the Seychelles. The move prompts a diplomatic tussle with Tunisia, which seeks his extradition.
April - Seychelles signs a tax exchange agreement with The Isle of Man, as part of moves to develop closer economic and taxation co-operation.
December - President James Michel wins a third term by the narrowest of margins, beating Seychelles National Party leader Wavel Ramkalawan.
May - Seychelles becomes one of a minority of African countries to decriminalise gay sex.
September - Opposition LDS wins parliamentary elections, breaking the ruling party's four-decade grip on power.
2017November - The Seychelles features in the
leak dubbed the Paradise Papers, which reveal the financial dealings of politicians, celebrities, corporate giants and business leaders.
February - Seychelles announces plans to create a marine reserve as part of a national debt swap deal which could serve as a model for future conservation projects around the world.

October -  Wavel Ramkalawan wins the presidency in the first peaceful transfer of presidential power between different parties since independence in 1976. His Linyon Demokratik Seselwa also wins parliamentary elections.
